description:
Entamoeba histolytica HM-1:IMSS-B is a protozoan parasite that belongs to the genus Entamoeba and is the causative agent of human amoebiasis, a serious gastrointestinal disease. This particular strain, HM-1:IMSS-B, is a well-studied laboratory isolate that has been used extensively in research.

E. histolytica is a single-celled eukaryotic organism that exists in two main forms: the infectious cyst and the pathogenic trophozoite. The cyst is the dormant, environmentally resistant stage, while the trophozoite is the actively feeding and invasive form. The HM-1:IMSS-B strain is a highly virulent and invasive trophozoite that can cause severe tissue damage and inflammation in the human intestine and liver.

Genetically, the HM-1:IMSS-B strain has been sequenced and found to possess a complex genome with a high degree of genetic diversity, which contributes to its adaptability and pathogenicity. The parasite uses a variety of virulence factors, such as cytolytic proteins and proteases, to invade and destroy host cells, leading to the development of amoebic dysentery and liver abscesses.

Understanding the biology and pathogenesis of the HM-1:IMSS-B strain has been crucial for the development of effective treatment strategies and the study of the host-parasite interactions involved in amoebiasis. This strain continues to be an important model organism in the field of parasitology and infectious disease research.
